Definitions: Hypertext Transfer Protocol (HTTP) is an application layer protocol that allows the transfer of resources on the World Wide Web.
A host refers to a computer or device on a network that provides services or resources to other computers or devices.
A port is a communication endpoint in an operating system that allows multiple processes to share a single network connection.
In the context of HTTP, a header is a part of the request or response message that carries additional information.
Encryption is the process of converting data into a format that is unreadable by unauthorized users, ensuring data security.
Framing in networking refers to the division of data into manageable units called frames for efficient transmission and reception.
GET is an HTTP method used to retrieve resources from a server.
POST is an HTTP method used to submit data to be processed by a specified resource.
A Uniform Resource Locator (URL) is a web address that specifies the location of a resource on the internet.
A status code is a three-digit number sent by a server as part of an HTTP response to indicate the status of the request.
